text:
(1)
Oakwood Beach (Staten Island): Shown is the hermitage of Dr. Clarence Stelton.
February 13, 1911.

By Wm. T. Davis through P.L. Sperr

(2)
A row of beachcombers' shacks at Oakwood Beach.
November 3, 1926.

P.L. Sperr

(3)
Frank's shack, home of a man who has lived twenty or thirty years as a beachcomber.
November 3, 1926.

P.L. Sperr
title: Staten Island - Oakwood Beach - [Beachcombers' shacks.]

text:
Oakwood Beach (Staten Island): Evidence of the perennial struggle of the sea against the land. The ocean is seen eating into the salt meadow.

May 22, 1925.

P.L. Sperr

(2)

The beach at low tide.

May 23, 1925.

P.L. Sperr

(3)

A promontory from the salt meadows.

May 23, 1925.

P.L. Sperr

text:
(1)
Oakwood Beach (Staten Island): shown are bits of salt meadow at low tide. At high tide these are entirely inundated.
P.L. Sperr

(2)
The same, another view.
P.L. Sperr

(3)
An extensive view of the beach and bits of salt meadow.
P.L. Sperr
July 1, 1925.

text:
(1)
Oakwood Beach (Staten Island): A beachcomber's shack with the ironic inscription: The Lonesome Millionaires..
P.L. Sperr

(2)
Another shack, at the beach. In the foreground is a broken wheel of the old Lake tidewater mill.
P.L. Sperr

(3)
The improvised home of a Staten Island beachcomber.
P.L. Sperr
title: Staten Island - Oakwood Beach - [Beachcombers.]

text:
(1)

Oakwood Beach (Staten Island): Where the ocean is cutting into the salt meadow, seen at low tide. Mr. Sperr states that the diving board is completely submerged at high tide.

P.L. Sperr

(2)

The same, another view.

P.L. Sperr

July 22, 1926
